item.title: Using Music And Rhythm To Help Kids With Grammar And Language
item.description: June 1, 2017 - Researchers at Vanderbilt University Medical Center are studying how music and rhythm activities could help children who struggle with grammar and language development.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 1, 2017 - Researchers at Vanderbilt University Medical Center are studying how music and rhythm activities could help children who struggle with grammar and language development. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/01/530723046/using-music-and-rhythm-to-help-kids-with-grammar-and-language

item.title: 3.6 Percent Of Americans Found To Have Food Allergies Or Intolerances
item.description: June 1, 2017 - A new study by researchers at Brigham and Women's Hospital finds that women and people of Asian descent are the most at risk and that shellfish is the most common allergen.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 1, 2017 - A new study by researchers at Brigham and Women's Hospital finds that women and people of Asian descent are the most at risk and that shellfish is the most common allergen. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/06/01/531088344/3-6-percent-of-americans-found-to-have-food-allergies-or-intolerances

item.title: Cracking The Code That Lets The Brain ID Any Face, Fast
item.description: June 1, 2017 - People and other primates have an amazing ability to instantly recognize faces. Scientists at Caltech found that we do that by having 205 specialized brain cells divvy up the task.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 1, 2017 - People and other primates have an amazing ability to instantly recognize faces. Scientists at Caltech found that we do that by having 205 specialized brain cells divvy up the task. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/01/530925382/cracking-the-code-that-lets-the-brain-id-any-face-fast

item.title: How Restricting Abortion Access Affects Rural America
item.description: June 1, 2017 - In many towns, the only access to care comes from clinics that also offer abortions. As these facilities continue to be shut down, how can women's healthcare needs be addressed?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 1, 2017 - In many towns, the only access to care comes from clinics that also offer abortions. As these facilities continue to be shut down, how can women's healthcare needs be addressed? http://the1a.org/shows/2017-06-01/how-restricting-abortion-access-affects-rural-america

item.title: The Making Of Emotions, From Pleasurable Fear To Bittersweet Relief
item.description: June 1, 2017 - Since ancient times, philosophers and scientists have viewed emotions as innate. In the latest Invisibilia, a psychologist argues that emotions spring from the sum of our experiences, not just wiring.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 1, 2017 - Since ancient times, philosophers and scientists have viewed emotions as innate. In the latest Invisibilia, a psychologist argues that emotions spring from the sum of our experiences, not just wiring. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/01/530103479/the-making-of-emotions-from-pleasurable-fear-to-bittersweet-relief

item.title: Invisibilia: A Man Finds An Explosive Emotion Locked In A Word
item.description: June 1, 2017 - When anthropologist Renato Rosaldo went to live with a Philippine tribe that was known for beheading people, he couldn't grasp the emotion that fueled this violence. Then his wife suddenly died.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 1, 2017 - When anthropologist Renato Rosaldo went to live with a Philippine tribe that was known for beheading people, he couldn't grasp the emotion that fueled this violence. Then his wife suddenly died. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/01/529876861/an-anthropologist-discovers-the-terrible-emotion-locked-in-a-word

item.title: Ohio Sues 5 Major Drug Companies For 'Fueling Opioid Epidemic'
item.description: May 31, 2017 - The state's attorney general filed the lawsuit Wednesday, alleging fraudulent marketing. "They knew they were wrong," Mike DeWine says, "but they did it anyway — and they continue to do it."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 31, 2017 - The state's attorney general filed the lawsuit Wednesday, alleging fraudulent marketing. "They knew they were wrong," Mike DeWine says, "but they did it anyway — and they continue to do it." http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/31/530929307/ohio-sues-5-major-drug-companies-for-fueling-opioid-epidemic

item.title: Meet A Home Contractor Who Helps Older People Age In Place
item.description: May 31, 2017 - Leon Watts of Los Angeles has seen his clients' needs change as they've aged. He decided he could do even more for them if he got a master's degree in gerontology.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 31, 2017 - Leon Watts of Los Angeles has seen his clients' needs change as they've aged. He decided he could do even more for them if he got a master's degree in gerontology. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/31/528949740/meet-a-home-contractor-who-helps-older-people-age-in-place

item.title: Ohio Sues Drug Companies Over Role In Creating Opioid Epidemic
item.description: May 31, 2017 - NPR's Robert Siegel talks with Ohio Attorney General Mike DeWine about his decision to sue five pharmaceutical companies over their role in creating the current opioid epidemic.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 31, 2017 - NPR's Robert Siegel talks with Ohio Attorney General Mike DeWine about his decision to sue five pharmaceutical companies over their role in creating the current opioid epidemic. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/31/530929951/ohio-sues-drug-companies-over-role-in-creating-opioid-epidemic

item.title: Research Shows How PTSD Can Trigger Growth In Veterans
item.description: May 31, 2017 - Some troops return from war only to face a new fight — symptoms of PTSD. But everything that follows traumatic experiences isn't bad. In fact, research shows they can actually trigger growth.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 31, 2017 - Some troops return from war only to face a new fight — symptoms of PTSD. But everything that follows traumatic experiences isn't bad. In fact, research shows they can actually trigger growth. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/31/530929915/research-shows-how-ptsd-can-trigger-growth-in-veterans

item.title: 'Like Brain Boot Camp': Using Music To Ease Hearing Loss
item.description: May 31, 2017 - Researchers in Toronto are studying whether singing in a choir and practicing pitch can help hearing-impaired people function better in noisy environments.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 31, 2017 - Researchers in Toronto are studying whether singing in a choir and practicing pitch can help hearing-impaired people function better in noisy environments. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/31/530723021/like-brain-boot-camp-using-music-to-ease-hearing-loss

item.title: We Asked, You Answered: Does U.S. Foreign Aid Raise Living Standards?
item.description:
May 31, 2017 - Researchers are split on the issue. We asked our audience to weigh in.
- http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/05/31/530227945/we-asked-you-answered-does-u-s-foreign-aid-raise-living-standards

item.title: Medicare Advantage Insurers Settle Whistleblower Suit For $32 Million
item.description: May 31, 2017 - A former medical director at two Florida insurance companies alleged the companies inflated fees by making patients appear sicker than they were or exaggerating the treatment that was provided.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 31, 2017 - A former medical director at two Florida insurance companies alleged the companies inflated fees by making patients appear sicker than they were or exaggerating the treatment that was provided. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/31/530868367/medicare-advantage-insurers-settle-whistleblower-suit-for-32-million

item.title: Poll: Americans Increasingly Think Their Health Care Will Get Worse
item.description: May 31, 2017 - A survey by the Kaiser Family Foundation found that about half of adults now have a favorable view of the Affordable Care Act, or Obamacare, while one-third prefer the Republican alternative.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 31, 2017 - A survey by the Kaiser Family Foundation found that about half of adults now have a favorable view of the Affordable Care Act, or Obamacare, while one-third prefer the Republican alternative. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/31/530843602/poll-americans-increasingly-think-their-health-care-will-get-worse

item.title: New Rules May Make Online Health Insurance Sales Simpler
item.description: May 31, 2017 - A rules change lets insurers and brokers sell health coverage on the federal exchange directly. That should be easier, but also raises questions about whether customers get unbiased information.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 31, 2017 - A rules change lets insurers and brokers sell health coverage on the federal exchange directly. That should be easier, but also raises questions about whether customers get unbiased information. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/31/530724704/new-rules-may-make-online-health-insurance-sales-simpler
